subject: JMTUnit problem
msgSnippet: Hello, I ve downloaded JMTUnit and trying to run the built in test. (I have not made any changes to the program - it is all from the JUnit site) The program
messageBody:
Hello,

I've downloaded JMTUnit and trying to run the built in test. (I have
not made any changes to the program - it is all from the JUnit site)
The program just stalls at the TestConfig constructor, specifically
at:
DOMParser parse = new DOMParser();

after adding the following catch statement:
catch(Throwable e){
e.printStackTrace();
}

this is the error that is being generated:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser
java.lang.Throwable(java.lang.String)
java.lang.Error(java.lang.String)
java.lang.LinkageError(java.lang.String)
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError(java.lang.String)
JMTUnit.TestConfig(java.lang.String)
JMTUnit.TestConfig(java.lang.String)
JMTUnit.TestStatistics JMTUnit.TestSuite.run(JMTUnit.TestCase)
void test.test.main(java.lang.String [])


Why is that? I am running the JMTUnit on Visual Age for Java. I do
have org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser.

Please help.

Thank you,

Lily

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 31, 2003 1:12 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test console output?



>So said jxingtang on 2003-07-30 --------------------
>> >A further question for StringWriter manipulation. Since I have to
>> >test several methods with console output which share the same
>> >StringWriter wrapped in the PrinterWriter. The problem is how to
>> >clean up the buffer after one test case. flush() method seems not
>> >work as expected.
>>
>> Why do you have to share the same StringWriter for each test? Just
>create a new one.

>I have found a way to solve the problem. I calls the getBuffer()to
>get the string buffer from the StringWriter and delete its content.
>
>The reason for me to share the StringWriter is that I do not want to
>construct a new class instance being tested for each method. I only
>construct on in setUp(). Here are of my code snippets.

I have news for you: setUp() is called for each test. You are creating the
extra StringWriter every time, anyway.

Don't worry about it. These aren't performance tests. Just create a new one
each time.

>public class MyClass
>{
> private PrintWriter MyWriter;
>
> // Constructor for production release
> public MyClass()
> {
> MyWriter = new PrintWriter( System.out );
> }
>
> // Constructor for Junit testing
> public MyClass( PrintWriter pw )
> {
> MyWriter = pw;
> }
>
> public void DumpOutput( Vector params )
> {
> // Clip ...
> }
>};
>
>public class MyClassTest extends TestCase
>{
> private MyClass MyTestObj = null;
>
> private StringWriter StrWriter = null;
>
> // Clip ...
>
> protected void setUp()
> {
> StrWriter = new StringWriter();
> PrintWriter prWriter = new PrintWriter( StrWriter );
> TestObj = new MyClass( prWriter );
> }
>
> public DumpOutputTest()
> {
> Vector testParams = new Vector();
> // Testcase 1
> testParams.addElement( "A" );
> testParams.addElement( "B" );
> testParams.addElement( "C" );
>
> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>
> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>
> // Code to evaluate outStr
> // Clip ....
>
> // Clean buffer of StringWriter
> StringBuffer sbuff = StrWriter.getBuffer();
> sbuff.delete( 0, outStr.length());
>
> // Testcase 2
> testParams.addElement( "X" );
> testParams.addElement( "Y" );
> testParams.addElement( "Z" );
>
> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>
> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>
> // Code to evaluate outStr
> // Clip ....
> }
>
> // Clip ...
>};
>
>Please give your valuable comments for my further correction and
>improvements.

Why are you writing multiple tests in a single method? Each test should be
its own method. You defeat the point of JUnit by using it this way.

Take care.

'
J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
